skills.name: Form expressions from situations described in words
Represent an equation using a bar model

explanations.A: Not quite. 3 red rectangles are longer than one purple rectangle. Which length in the diagram is the same as 3r?
explanations.B: Be careful. 3w means the length of 3 white rectangles. Looking at the diagram we can see 3 red rectangles are longer than three white rectangles. Which length in the diagram is the same as 3r?
explanations.C: Not quite. 3 red rectangles are shorter than two purple rectangles. Which length in the diagram is the same as 3r?
explanations.D: Looking at the key given below the diagram, 3r = 3 red rectangles. It can be seen from the diagram that 3 of the red rectangles start and end in line with 2 of the green rectangles, and so 3r = 2g.

explanations.A: Not quite. 2 purple rectangles are shorter than three green rectangles. Which length in the diagram is the same as 2p?
explanations.B: Not quite. 2 purple rectangles are shorter than five red rectangles. Which length in the diagram is the same as 2p?
explanations.C: Looking at the key given below the diagram, 2p = 2 purple rectangles. It can be seen from the diagram that 2 of the purple rectangles start and end in line with 8 of the white rectangles, and so 2p = 8w.
explanations.D: Not quite. 2 purple rectangles are shorter than eight red rectangles (as only 6 are shown in the diagram). Which length in the diagram is the same as 2p?

explanations.A: Since 2w = 1r, it follows that 2w ï¼‹ r is the same as 2r. It can be seen from the diagram that 2 of the red rectangles (2r) start and end in line with 1 of the purple rectangles, and so 2r = 1p = p.
explanations.B: Not quite. Using the key, 2w means 2 white rectangles and r stands for 1 red rectangle. Can you find the length that will be equal to the total length 2w + r? Finding the relationship between the white and red rectangles will help you do this.
explanations.C: Not quite. Using the key, 2w means 2 white rectangles and r stands for 1 red rectangle. Can you find the length that will be equal to the total length 2w + r? Finding the relationship between the white and red rectangles will help you do this.
explanations.D: Not quite. Using the key, 2w means 2 white rectangles and r stands for 1 red rectangle. Can you find the length that will be equal to the total length 2w + r? Finding the relationship between the white and red rectangles will help you do this.

explanations.A: Not quite. Using the key, 2g means 2 green rectangles and 3r stands for 3 red rectangles. Can you find the length that will be equal to the total length 2g + 3r? Finding the relationship between the green and red rectangles will help you do this.
explanations.B: Not quite. Using the key, 2g means 2 green rectangles and 3r stands for 3 red rectangles. Can you find the length that will be equal to the total length 2g + 3r? Finding the relationship between the green and red rectangles will help you do this.
explanations.C: Since 3r = 2g, we can say that 2g ï¼‹ 3r = 2g ï¼‹ 2g = 4g. It can be seen from the diagram that 4 of the green rectangles (4g) start and end in line with 3 of the purple rectangles, and so this is the same as 3p.
explanations.D: Not quite. Using the key, 2g means 2 green rectangles and 3r stands for 3 red rectangles. Can you find the length that will be equal to the total length 2g + 3r? Finding the relationship between the green and red rectangles will help you do this.

explanations.A: The diagram shows that 3 of the white rectangles start and end in line with 1 of the green rectangles, and so 3w = g. Dividing both sides by 3 gives us Tomâ€™s equation w = g/3. Katieâ€™s equation is incorrect because it can be seen from the diagram that 4w = p.
explanations.B: Not quite. w = 4p means one white rectangle is the same length as four purple rectangles. The diagram shows the reverse is true, in fact w = p/4.
explanations.C: Not quite. Have a look again at the diagram and Tom and Katie's equations. Does the diagram show the relationships that they have found? To help, w = 4p means the length of one white rectangle is the same as 4 purple rectangles.
explanations.D: Not quite. At least one of the students is correct. Have a look again at the diagram to see if it matches Tom and Katie's equations. To help, w = 4p means the length of one white rectangle is the same as 4 purple rectangles.

explanations.A: Not quite. w = 3g means one white rectangle is the same length as three green rectangles. The diagram shows the reverse is true, in fact w = g/3.
explanations.B: The diagram shows that 3 of the white rectangles start and end in line with 1 of the green rectangles, and so 3w = g, meaning Joâ€™s statement is incorrect. For Paulâ€™s statement, the diagram shows that 4w = 1p. Dividing both sides by 4 gives us w = p/4, which is Paulâ€™s equation.
explanations.C: Not quite. Have a look again at the diagram and Jo and Paul's equations. Does the diagram show the relationships that they have found? To help, w = 3g means the length of one white rectangle is the same as 3 green rectangles.
explanations.D: Not quite. At least one of the students is correct. Have a look again at the diagram to see if it matches Tom and Katie's equations. To help, w = 3g means the length of one white rectangle is the same as 3 green rectangles.

explanations.A: Be careful. All the terms in this equation are being added but the question is saying that the number is being multiplied by 4. How would we write this down using algebra?
explanations.B: Letâ€™s call this number ğ‘›. When it is multiplied by 4, it becomes 4 Ã— ğ‘› = 4ğ‘›. If 5 is then added on, we have the complete expression 4ğ‘› + 5. We are told that this equals 17 so 4n + 5 = 17.
explanations.C: Be careful! nâ´ does not mean 4 multiplied by n, it means n âœ• n âœ• n âœ• n. How would we write "multiply the number by 4" using algebra?
explanations.D: Not quite. Have another look at the question. You want to multiply the number by 4 and then add 5. This expression says, because of the brackets, add 5 to your number and then multiply by 4.

explanations.A: Be careful! nÂ³ does not mean 3 multiplied by n, it means n âœ• n âœ• n. How would we write "multiply your number by 3" using algebra?
explanations.B: Not quite. Have another look at the question. You want to multiply the number by 3 and then subtract 6. This expression says, because of the brackets, subtract 6 from the number and then multiply by 3.
explanations.C: Be careful! 3 + n does not mean 3 multiplied by n, it means add 3 to n. How would we write "multiply the number by 3" using algebra?
explanations.D: Letâ€™s call this number ğ‘›. When it is multiplied by 3, it becomes 3 Ã— ğ‘› = 3ğ‘›. If 6 is then subtracted, we have the complete expression 3ğ‘› âˆ’ 6. We are told that this equals 21 so 3n - 6 = 21.

explanations.A: Not quite. Using the order of operations, n + 5 âœ• 4 means multiply 5 by 4 and then add n. This is not the same as the question. What would we need to use to show that we wanted to add 5 before we multiplied by 4?
explanations.B: Not quite. Using the order of operations, 4n + 5 means multiply n by 4 and then add 5. This is not the same as the question. What would we need to use to show that we wanted to add 5 before we multiplied by 4?
explanations.C: Be careful. nâ´ = n âœ• n âœ• n âœ• n. This is not the same as multiplying the result by 4.
explanations.D: Letâ€™s call this number ğ‘›. When it has 5 added on, it becomes 5 + ğ‘›. â€˜Multiply the result by fourâ€™ tells us that all of 5 + ğ‘› must be multiplied by 4. To achieve this mathematically, brackets are used: 4(ğ‘› + 5). We are told that this equals 17, so 4(ğ‘› + 5) = 17

explanations.A: Be careful. nÂ³ = n âœ• n âœ• n . This is not the same as multiplying the result by 3.
explanations.B: Letâ€™s call this number ğ‘›. When it has 6 subtracted, it becomes ğ‘› âˆ’ 6. â€˜Multiply the result by threeâ€™ tells us that all of ğ‘› âˆ’ 6 must be multiplied by 3. To achieve this mathematically, brackets are used: 3(ğ‘› âˆ’ 6). We are told that this is 21, so, 3(ğ‘› âˆ’ 6) = 21
explanations.C: Not quite. Using the order of operations, n - 6 âœ• 3 means multiply 6 by 3 and then subtract this from n. This is not the same as the question. What would we need to use to show that we wanted to subtract 6 before we multiplied by 3?
explanations.D: Not quite. Using the order of operations, 3n - 6 means multiply n by 3 and then subtract 6. This is not the same as the question. What would we need to use to show that we wanted to subtract 6 before we multiplied by 3?
